column4: if i want to install a new kernel, i in theory can do it via aptitude privided their exists a compatible one available right? what about actually making that kernel boot: i need to muck about with grub for that don't i?
you should be getting kernel upgrades from APT automatically with update-manager and they will automatically be setup for you
i need to downgrade kernel as it currently refuses to boot on i686 (amd geode cpu)
have you found the relevant bug report?
uhm no....
you need to provide more details.  Did ubuntu boot with an older kernel and then update-manager gave a new one and this one now fails?
summarize it

I have a thin client running on an AMD GX1 cpu with a 4.6gb laptop harddisk in it. it has no cd drive or spare id controller and cannot boot off of usb. the only option was for me to put the laptop disk into a laptop (the one im using now) and install ubuntu server edition from there. unfortunately the laptop has a modern pentium m cpu which works an i686 kernel. so after installing and putting the harddisk back into the thin client, the thin client refu
uname -r
what does 'uname -r' return?
boot it on the laptop and come back here
oh the kernel version is 2.6.26 i think
my guess is it's using -generic.  That works on most cpu
if it is on generic is there any way i can change it to a i586,486 or 386??
/msg ubottu info linux-image-i386
erm, ignore that
there are -386 kernels in APT.  Let me check what the documentation says about your processor though
hmm, I can't find the documentation that would tell me what the right kernel for your processor is.  I guess you can just try the -386 one and see what happens
do u know what apt-get install * i need?
the metapackage is linux-386.  You probably still need to choose the -386 kernel from the grub boot menu when you boot
your earlier help with the kernel stuff worked... thanks :)
